article.Heading: Budget 2016: Govt to set aside Rs 1000 crore for higher education financing
article.Summary: Despite government spending on education having more than doubled over the last decade, the system is suffering from poorly trained teachers, (and consequently quality of teaching) and a high drop-out rate among the poor.
article.Body:
Sidhartha Shukla
moneycontrol.com

Finance Minister, Arun Jaitley has proposed to set up a higher education financing agency and has allocated Rs 1000 crore for the same in the Union Budget-2016.

In his Budget speech Jaitley said that the governement aims to skill 1 crore youth in the next 3 years under the PM Kaushal Vikas Yojana.

The National Skill Development Mission has imparted training to 76 lakh citizens and 1500 multi skill training institutes are to be set up in the future for which Rs 1700 crore are set aside, he said.

The government further plans to open 62 new Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya’s and start a digital literacy scheme for rural India.

In last year's Budget, allocation to the education sector including mid-day meals was trimmed to Rs 68,968 crore from Rs 70,505 crore allotted in the previous budget.

A higher Budget for basic education may not necessarily be the answer to India’s problem of low adult literacy rates compared to other BRICS nations.

Despite government spending on education having more than doubled over the last decade, the system is suffering from poorly trained teachers, (and consequently quality of teaching) and a high drop-out rate among the poor.
